Articles.Content: So, I had just gotten my first piece to my space station up into orbit. I extend the solar panels, and then turn on the lights because I was on the dark side of the planet. Not only did the lights light up my craft, it also lit up the planet.
Maybe Kerbals invented it because even if they are not affraid of an fiery explody death they are affraid of the dark.

Is this the Illuminator Mk3?

WAIT

Mk3, three is illuminati

And it's called "illuminator"

DOUBLE LOOMINARTY PLANET DOOMSDAY ALIEN GEORGE BUSH OBAMA SPOTLIGHT AREA 51 MIND CONTROL ANTI-GUN RIGHTS PLOT.
See? The death star didn't blow up planets, it just lit them up.
Could we have a pic of the station to see its vegetation-scorching glory?

Do you use The RokoLite adapter from this mod?

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/90438-WIP-New-Wheels-multipurpose-parts-landinglegs-Beam-Axles

Clickable. That's the lights!

http://i.imgur.com/XfQuQZ7l.png

Dude. I'm speechless! +Rep!

This is a rare glitch that comes up from time to time. Sometimes, the direction of the illumination rotates slowly in the vertical plane. It used to happen a lot with Tosh's cart mod, but I've seen it in stock once or twice as well.
Are they the B9 spotlights? It happens to me in time warp all the time when I use them.
Might strap a couple to some satellites and do away with the pesky night.

Might strap a couple to some satellites and do away with the pesky night.

I try that. I wanted to light Kerbin and it never get dark anywhere on the surface. It happened all the time for me and I thought it was just game design not a quirk. Some calculations using internet searches excessively, trying to figure out the minium number of satellites needed and orbits to place them in.

The first satellite I launched focused on this endeavor did not light the surface. I figured I have choosen the wrong light and tried again. Long story short it has been hit and miss for me. I can send a satellite with lights and it illuminates the surface. The next one of the same design does not.
Ya, I think they are the B9 spotlights.
I suppose any spotlight that have such power would melt anything it installed on

OLED = super lumens, tiny heat loss. You could definitely light up a planet from space with OLEDs [/amirite]
